results.title: First principles of editing
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Video tech”.
Focuses on basic editing principles - making the decision about what to include in a video story and what to omit. Investigates the reasons it is essential to edit - to eliminate unwanted footage, to compress time and to ultimately make a program more interesting. It also looks at the needs of in-camera editing such as planning a shoot, shooting in sequence and shot duration. It also covers the needs of editing between camcorder and VCR, setting up at home and crash editing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: On screen direction
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode examines the process of on-screen direction. It details the technical orchestration of setting up the shoot, camera position, visual sequences needed, actuality shots and the direction of people through constant communication and the defining of roles and functions for all people involved. It also explores the requirements for directing special talent including children and animals, and their special needs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: Crew roles and responsibilities
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode focuses on the camera crew - who’s who and how they do their jobs. The size of the video crew depends on the size of the story to be presented, but there are three essential crew members - the presenter, the sound recordist and the camera operator. The role of each of these in the production of a video story is thoroughly examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: Visual story telling
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Video tech”.
This program presents a structured look at the practice and technique of video story telling. It looks at the sequencing of shots and how they work to advance a story, the planning of shots, the shooting of a sequence and the placement of the camera when shooting. It focusses on continuity and the factors to watch when editing so that shots will flow from one to the other and not seem illogical in the finished product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.description:

results.title: The Interview, the 180 rule
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Video tech”.
This program focusses on the television interview. It analyses camera position, the use of light, shot composition, and also the questions - what to ask, when to ask and how to ask! It also includes other important points to remember, such as backcuts, noddies and not crossing the line.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.description:

results.title: Story structures: finding the hook
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Video tech”.
Focuses on video storytelling through the analysis of story structure, telling the story, finding the hook to keep people interested, and visualising the story. It explores the six basic questions which must be answered in a story: Who? What? When? Where? Why? and How?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: Researching the story
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode overviews the first part of storytelling - finding a story people can relate to. It describes research techniques such as defining what is a story, story telling styles, finding the angle, getting the facts, developing sources, finding the people, preparing the shoot, briefing the crew and meeting deadlines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: Shooting on location
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at light and how the camera responds to it. It shows how to get good pictures shooting at night and using light creatively.

results.title: Video sound
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at background noise and how to reduce it. It explains the uses of single, wide or omni-directional microphones, extension mikes and their placement (especially with interviews or music), directional mikes and how to use them together effectively.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions

results.title: The Moving camera, the moving subject
results.creator_credit: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Video tech”.
This episode looks at the art of shooting movement. The composition of shots with a moving subject, such as walking room and depth of field, what happens when the subject moves, and how to deal with holding the action and combinations of movements are highlighted. Demonstrates the techniques of using a moving camera, such as tripod moves, zooming and tracking.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lynn John, John A. Givins and KTV Productions
